text:
```How do I switch "Best Price Execution" on or off?

The Best Price Execution feature is switched on by default for all customers and this is Betfair's recommended setting. However, if you are resident in the UK and if you would  would like to disable the Best Price Execution feature, there is a toggle that allows you to switch it off at any time. 

On desktop, you can find the toggle by navigating to the "Betting" tab from the "Settings" menu. 
On mobile, you can find the toggle by going to "Settings" from the A-Z menu and then selecting "Best Price Execution".```

elements.text:
How do I switch "Best Price Execution" on or off?

The Best Price Execution feature is switched on by default for all customers and this is Betfair's recommended setting. However, if you are resident in the UK and if you would  would like to disable the Best Price Execution feature, there is a toggle that allows you to switch it off at any time. 

On desktop, you can find the toggle by navigating to the "Betting" tab from the "Settings" menu. 
On mobile, you can find the toggle by going to "Settings" from the A-Z menu and then selecting "Best Price Execution".

text: If you have BPE disabled, you get an error if BPE is used to get you matched, e.g. you ask for a BACK at 5.0 but the best price is now 5.2 you would get an error with the size fully lapsed regardless of the amount available at 5.2

text: Don't think this is really at odds with message passing; redis has the added benefit that you can use its key-value store for the data that's "more" static that you just want to query, and pub/sub reserved for anything dynamic you want to pass between processes

text:
Betfair distributed event stream using kafka -> streaming client (nice and simple per client and scalable as Betfair handle that)

Betfair distributed event stream using kafka -> streaming -> redis -> client (not simple and involves redis scaling)

You would basically be replicating the problem betfair has already solved and then trying to solve it again yourself

elements.text:

You would basically be replicating the problem betfair has already solved and then trying to solve it again yourself

text:
```from flumine import FlumineBacktest, clients

client = clients.BacktestClient()
framework = FlumineBacktest(client=client)

strategy = ExampleStrategy(
    market_filter={"markets": ["/tmp/marketdata/1.170212754"]}
)
framework.add_strategy(strategy)

framework.run()```
isn’t it more hassle to spin up own data recorders? I guess depends on use case

)

framework.run()
